text:
Hi!
Today we launched Fibery. It is a connected workspace for teams. In a nutshell, you can build your internal tools in Fibery with no-code. It would be great to have a feedback of this super wise community :slightly_smiling_face: <https://www.producthunt.com/posts/fibery-3>

attachments.title: Fibery - Connected workspace for teams | Product Hunt
attachments.text: Create a workspace that brings teams together: sales :hearts: marketing :hearts: product :hearts: R&D. Escape costly scattered tools and unreliable integrations by having goals, projects, customers, and docs connected in Fibery.
attachments.fallback: Product Hunt: Fibery - Connected workspace for teams | Product Hunt

text: Do you have a link to a technical writeup or blog post about the making of this tool?

elements.text: Do you have a link to a technical writeup or blog post about the making of this tool?

text:
If you mean high level vision, here is it <https://medium.com/fibery/fibery-getting-started-64bd0839c85a>

If you mean technologies behind, then we don’t have it so far. In short it was built on Clojure (core for flexible domain) + Javascript for quite many side services + Postgres (works surprisingly well for flexible domain, we selected it instead of graph database).

attachments.title: Fibery.io Vision: Getting Started
attachments.text: This post is for the early adopters. At this moment Fibery has zero attention to getting started, and the most curious people will find…

text:
Intentionally, without any context, I want to share a concept to see what peoples temperature of it is. `Dialog Driven Development`
What does that mean to you? Does it seem inviting/interesting/futuristic/inclusive?

elements.text: Intentionally, without any context, I want to share a concept to see what peoples temperature of it is.
Dialog Driven Development
What does that mean to you? Does it seem inviting/interesting/futuristic/inclusive?

text: Now, for more context. Think Star Trek when Pike talks to the computer. He can ask complex questions and create complex procedures with just his voice, but the computer will have a dialog with him to get all the necessary context to achieve what he is asking for. As the idea of Dialog Driven Development is to focus more on the conversation with the user instead diagram/visual development and traditional coding.

elements.text: Now, for more context. Think Star Trek when Pike talks to the computer. text: I think prototype conversations would be really interesting to see. Like, given the user is trying to write a calculator, what is the ideal back and forth that lets them do that. My hypothesis is that these would demonstrate that the software needs to already have sophisticated abstractions that make a lot of decisions for you. I think without that, the decision tree would get too deep/complex.

text: <@UKDM3GLAJ> Thank you for your insight :slightly_smiling_face: I think I’m getting a different kind of question from you: What is the domain? I would not expect someone to build a calculator with voice but I would expect them to, for example, track high-value customers with open support tickets. More EUSE cases than GPPL cases.

elements.text: Thank you for your insight

I think I’m getting a different kind of question from you: What is the domain? I would not expect someone to build a calculator with voice but I would expect them to, for example, track high-value customers with open support tickets. More EUSE cases than GPPL cases.

text: <@UMYKGHYBA> Cool stuff! I reviewed your videos and content. Great messaging too! Your videos are hilarious, great work, they feel really inclusive. I got the impression this was an alternative to perhaps Notion, Airtable, Asana, Jira or Basecamp. Focused mostly on CRM and knowledge. The disconnect for me was the no-code aspects, the concepts of “installing” templates felt strange (why not just “use” or “add”?) and the general positioning of the product feels at the crossroads of many tools that already exist in the market today. I empathize with the “all-in-one” approach however, the more and more you get all-in-one the more opinions start to form and the more rigid the product gets. I’m currently using Asana (IMO Jira is far to cumbersome) and Asana is really user freindly with a crazy amount of features,  I tried to keep an open mind yet at the same time I was thinking what really differentiates Fibrery to Asana? In my mind, this all circles back to it’s a project management tool. I would love to hear your reaction to this and see if you can help me fill in the gaps. Overall, I’m impressed and interested. I’m mostly curious as to what the largest customer/use case you have.

text:
Very first, high level impression/feelings I get when I hear the term:
- I think smth like "cool, sounds like I will be guided, which means it could be easy/simple to develop smth"
- on the other hand, it reminds of experience with Google assistant or similar solutions, which means it will be relatively slow and while I will be impressed at start, I will quickly get stuck with it not understanding me.

It would certainly interest me to learn more about it though, I would click on "Learn more" or "Try out".

text: A coroutine is a lightweight cooperative thread. An example use might be waiting on asynchronous operations (like i/o) without loosing the state you’ve built up in your call stack - as you’d end up having to construct an even more complex (and likely inscrutable) state machine otherwise. So when you make your call to wait on an i/o operation, behind the scenes it sets aside your current stack and continues some other coroutine (or returns to the event loop). When the i/o operation event occurs, that callback resumes (switches to) the previously paused coroutine’s stack. In this way, you can writing asynchronous code as if it were synchronous, while still being aware of where those points are via things like naming conventions on methods that may pause the coroutine. You can also yield coroutines at safe points so they can do long running computations with stacks.

elements.text: A coroutine is a lightweight cooperative thread. An example use might be waiting on asynchronous operations (like i/o) without loosing the state you’ve built up in your call stack - as you’d end up having to construct an even more complex (and likely inscrutable) state machine otherwise. So when you make your call to wait on an i/o operation, behind the scenes it sets aside your current stack and continues some other coroutine (or returns to the event loop). When the i/o operation event occurs, that callback resumes (switches to) the previously paused coroutine’s stack. In this way, you can writing asynchronous code as if it were synchronous, while still being aware of where those points are via things like naming conventions on methods that may pause the coroutine. You can also yield coroutines at safe points so they can do long running computations with stacks.

text:
I was chatting about the apparent lack of a dialog interface in "big data" type offerings. I'm not at all up to speed in the area; so there may be existing offerings I'm not aware of. The discussion was with a non-tech user who has to ask for custom reports to be built by his technical colleague; and would rather ask his platform- "Show me clients with highest percent increase in revenue in last two weeks of March"
Rather specific; but its on my list of things to look into; as it seems like a reasonable fit

text:
I like “dialog” because it implies both natural language and interaction/feedback.

One idle thought — is there a better word than “development”? That’s still kind of programmer jargon. For most people it probably means something different.

text: <@UJKKBAMLL> actually I personally better like to Dialog Driven, since it is similar to Test or Business Driven Development. Driven or guided, I don't think it changes the meaning.

text: <@UFB8STN7K> and <@UUB7RA7PF> — I agree with both your insights. Dialog driven ____? Could also be “oriented” but that feels like a loaded term. Development is also loaded. :thinking_face: I’m thinking Alexa, but with a UI and dope UX for business QA and workflows.
